documents.title: afternoon summary
text: gloria de piero , the shadow equalities minister has said labour will take action against class discrimination by asking public sector employers to monitor the social background of their workforce .
frances o'grady , the tuc general secretary , has urged labour to ignore business complaints about its plan to increase the national minimum wage .
she said : the predictable scaremongering from business about the impact of a rising minimum wage on jobs should be ignored .
they said the same in the 1990s before the minimum wage was introduced .
they were wrong then and they are wrong again now .
tristram hunt , the shadow education secretary , has said labour will bring back the school support staff negotiating body .
in a speech to the conference , angela rayner , labour 's prospective parliamentary candidate for ashton-under-lyme and a unison official , welcomed the move in a speech to the conference .
she said : support staff in education , who make up half of the school workforce , have been overlooked these last four years .

the government cuts have disproportionately affected support staff and our members have been largely ignored and their pay held down , their funding for training cut and their national training resources hidden .
len mccluskey , the unite general secretary , has described britain 's economic growth as phoney '' .
in a speech to a fringe meeting he said : there will be no sustainable recovery unless people are paid decent wages in real jobs .

we are witnessing a phoney growth , based on personal debt we are asked to believe that 4.5 million people are self employed , but that figure is a nonsense.these are people with no contracts , no rights , scrambling from day to day .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
here 's a short afternoon reading list .
jeremy cliffe at the economist says labour should accept english votes for english laws '' - on the condition that those votes are proportional .
a alternative suggests itself .
labour could back evel but insist that such votes be proportional ; pevel , as it were .
after all , the scottish , welsh and northern irish legislatures use proportional voting systems .
why should the body purporting to represent the democratic will of the english this would eradicate the two tory majorities keeping labour types up at night .
first , it would put mr cameron in a minority in the current evel debate .

the liberal democrats and the smaller parties ( most importantly , ukip ) would likely support pevel over evel ; there is a good chance that public opinion would also lean this way ( some canny pollster should ask english voters should the english have a proportional voice in the house of commons ? ''
to find out . )
the conservatives would look like the ones stalling out of self-interest .
second , if enacted , pevel would cut the conservatives ' voting strength in english-only votes ( under the 2010 result ) from 56 % to 40 % .
that would make the inbuilt tory blocking majority that labour fears virtually impossible ; even in its 1980s landslides , the party never won more than 46 % of votes in england .
mark ferguson at labourlist explains the challenge for ed miliband this week .
what 's clear though is that miliband has a huge task ahead of him .
unlike in previous years , there is no sense here that miliband 's position at leader is in question .
he will be the labour leader come the election in may - the only way things could have been otherwise passed with the no vote in scotland on thursday .
but the task ahead of him is perhaps harder still .
he must tie together the constitutional debates that have begun ( in political circles only ) and explain his solution to the disenchantment that people across britain feel .
he must rise to the challenge of convincing a sceptical british public that he has what it takes to be prime minister in just a matter of months .
and he must balance offering a big vision with offering attention grabbing policy promises that chime with that same sceptical electorate .
i do n't envy him - but that 's where the bar is set this week .
and he must cross it .

documents.title: hilary benn 's speech - summary
text: and here are the key points from the speech from hilary benn , the shadow communities secretary .
benn said labour 's plan for a constitutional convention was not an attempt to kick the issue of devolution to england into the long grass .
we will go further in changing the way decisions are made so that we can free local communities , the people of england , to shape their own destiny .
not something cooked up in corridors of whitehall , but a deeper , more profound change involving people from every part of the country .
a national debate - leading up to a constitutional convention - as fervent and as involved as the one that paved the way for devolution in scotland .
this is n't about the long grass ; it 's about the grass roots telling us what they want in the long term .
a convention with a purpose .
he said labour would give councils more control over new housing developments .
so instead of communities feeling that they ca n't influence where new homes go because developers ignore the sites the council has identified , and instead try to build somewhere else .
instead of communities saying that the design is poor , the rooms are too small , and the gp surgeries , roads and schools wo n't be there .
and instead of them thinking that even if the homes are built , that their children or friends or neighbours will never get one of them .

instead of all of this , we will give communities , as sir michael lyons ' report will recommend , the powers they need to tackle land banking ; put together the sites ; get the design right ; put in the infrastructure ; and work with small and medium-size and large builders to build the homes that local people need where local people want .
the results of the contemporary motions ballot have just been announced .
the six to chosen for debate are : low pay , rail , housing , nhs , global human rights and work in the contemporary economy .
this blog is normally a football-free zone , but there is no avoiding the traditional party conference sunday press gallery v labour match that took place earlier today .
ed balls , the shadow chancellor , is a regular for labour .
today he managed to hospitalise one of his opponents , my northern echo colleague rob merrick .

documents.title: gloria de piero 's speech - summary
text: gloria de piero is the shadow equalities minister .
here are the main points from her speech .
de piero said labour would make public sector employers monitor the social background of their recruits .
good companies already monitor the race , gender and disability of their staff .
they should monitor social background for the same reason .
the legal profession is already doing it , others should follow .
so today i can tell you today that a labour government will work to ensure this is done in the public sector .
she accused leading professions of excluding applicants from working-class backgrounds .
politics , law , journalism , business - wonderful jobs .
but they still operate like closed-shops .
three quarters of senior judges , nearly half of journalists - are from the private schools which educate just seven per cent of the population .
this is not an accident of talent .
this is inequality of opportunity entrenched in the recruitment practices of professions that hire in their own image .
she said the civil service should accept more working-class recruits .
the civil service should set the standard on open recruitment and open opportunity .
listen to the latest statistic .
of the 654 graduates who made it on to the civil service fast- stream , just 25 were from working class backgrounds .
she said britain should be class-blind .
it makes me angry .
conference , talent is class-blind , but britain is still not .
the ex-scottish union leader jimmy reid used to talk about looking behind the windows of every council estate and high-rise flat .
because behind every one of those windows - there is someone who might be a judge , a vice chancellor , a politician , a ceo .
look at alan johnson - all the way from the london slums to the cabinet table , never went to university , but an orwell book prize winner .
we need more of these stories .
she praised the rightwing spectator magazine for its internship scheme .
here 's a publication you do n't hear praised that often at a labour conference - the spectator magazine .
each summer it takes work experience kids from the social mobility foundation scheme giving bright students without connections that foot in the door .
i congratulate them for it .
it went down well with at least one labour colleague .

documents.title: tristram hunt 's speech
text: here 's the full text of the speech by tristram hunt , the shadow education secretary .
and here are the main points .
hunt said labour would bring back the school support staff negotiating body .
it was abolished by the coalition .
hunt said : the cleaners , janitors , dinner ladies , teaching assistants - the hidden army of our schools .
as our friends in unison , unite , and the gmb have long campaigned , it is time their contribution was recognised .
this tory government scrapped plans for a school support staff negotiating body .
conference , the next labour government will re-establish that negotiating body for the lowest paid ; to deliver dignity at work for those who ensure our young people succeed .
he said labour would extend the london challenge scheme , which raised standards in london school , across the country .
he said labour would not allow for-profit providers to run schools .
the conservatives have not ruled this out , he said .
warwick labour ( @ warwicklabour ) tristram hunt on stage # lab14 ^kathryn
a yougov poll for today 's sunday times ( paywall ) illustrates why david cameron is so keen to exploit the english votes for english laws '' issue .
here 's an extract from peter kellner 's commentary .
not surprisingly , 72 % of english voters think scottish mps should no longer have the vote in parliament on issues that affect only england .
perhaps more significantly , as many as 55 % also think that scottish mps should play no part in tax and spending decisions taken in london , even though these do affect life in scotland .
and almost two-thirds of english voters want to scrap the barnett formula that ensures scotland receives more public cash per person than england from central government .
kellner says this poses a specific problem for ed miliband , because he also needs to shore up labour support in scotland .
in practical terms , miliband needs to shore up labour 's support in scotland between now and next year 's election .
the risks and consequences of failure are great .
suppose that next spring scottish voters feel that london 's politicians have ratted on their pledge to act swiftly to transfer big new powers to scotland .
they might well turn to the scottish national party ( snp ) .
only three labour seats would be lost if there were a 5 % swing to the snp ; but then comes a tipping point .
an 8 % swing would cost labour 19 seats , and probably miliband 's hopes of becoming prime minister .

this means miliband must show scotland 's voters his commitment to further devolution is real , and not just a panic-driven reaction to yougov 's dramatic poll in this newspaper two weeks ago showing the collapse of the better together campaign 's lead north of the border .
but the more miliband offers scotland , the more he risks alienating england 's voters .
tristram hunt , the shadow education secretary , is speaking to the conference now .
i 'll post a summary when i 've seen the text of his speech .
comres has conducted a survey of the views of 73 labour candidates for the bbc 's sunday politics show .
the bbc write-up of the results focuses on the fact that a large proportion of them want to increase tax and scrap trident .
labour general election candidates support tax rises to reduce the deficit and are in favour of scrapping trident , new research for the bbc suggests .
an exclusive survey of 73 candidates for bbc1 's sunday politics found that 42 % backed raising taxes after 2015 as the main '' way to balance the books .
but the comres write-up highlights the fact that only 15 % think immigration is too high .
only 15 % of labour parliamentary candidates believe the level of immigration is too high according to a survey conducted for bbc1 's sunday politics programme .

the survey , conducted for the bbc by the polling agency comres , found that 89 % of labour parliamentary candidates they spoke to said they believe immigration from inside the eu is a good thing for britain and only 7 % saying they though that britain is too generous to immigrants .

asked about the level of public spending under the last labour government , 85 % of the candidates in our survey said the level of spending was about right '' , 10 % said it was too low '' with just 4 % saying it was too high '' .

asked how a future labour government should reduce the deficit , 42 % say it should be done mainly through raising taxes , 18 % by cutting spending , 7 % by increasing borrowing with 4 % saying there is no need to reduce the deficit .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: labour and the conservatives have both insisted that the new powers to scotland promised by westminster before the independence referendum will be implemented .

number 10 issued a clarification in the light of comments from david cameron and other senior tories suggesting the voting rights of scottish mps would have to be cut as a precondition for further devolution to go ahead .
( see 1.03pm . )
in an interview on the andrew marr show , ed miliband said the two issues should not be linked .
but the tories are still determined to make this an election issue .

after miliband 's interview grant shapps , the conservative chairman , said : ed miliband failed to answer a very simple question of fairness - does he believe only english mps should vote on laws that only affect england ?
sir william mckay , the former commons clerk who chaired a commission on the west lothian question , has hinted that stopping scottish mps voting on english-only laws may now be inevitable .
the mckay report , published last year , ruled out this idea on the grounds this would create two classes of mp .
instead it proposed limiting the rights of scottish mps to vote at certain points during the passage of legislation through parliament .
labour and the lib dems have both signalled they could accept these ideas .
but , on the world this weekend , mckay said the fact scotland would now be getting more devolution meant the proposals in his report were no longer satisfactory .
we tried [ in our report ] to avoid two classes of members .
you can vote here , but you ca n't vote there .
and finally , we said there has to be a provision for english voices , but the final decision must be taken by all uk members .
whether and to what extent these have been overtaken by the result of the referendum , i think is a very difficult question to answer .
but certainly you ca n't , i think , lower any of our solutions immediately , without amendment , into the present situation .
they will have to be tweaked a fairly hefty tweak , more of a kick than a tweak .
you would have to answer the basic question , can we still go along with the principle of not creating two sets of members ?
would you need to create an english voice which was a final voice ?

salmond has accused the leaders of the three main uk parties of tricking hundreds of thousands of voters into rejecting scotland 's independence by making a last-minute vow of more devolution which they are now abandoning .

in interviews , he also said that scottish independence was inevitable , that the uk leaving the eu could trigger a second referendum , and that a referendum might not be necessary for scotland to become independent .

lord ashdown , the former lib dem leader , has accused cameron of pretty disgraceful '' behaviour because of what he has said about linking further scottish independence with cutting the voting rights of scottish mps .
ashdown told sky news : mr cameron , quite deliberately to satisfy his backbenchers , and also to create a trap for labour , played politics with his own promise .
that 's pretty disgraceful anyway , to play politics with that promise is , in my view , extremely foolish and extremely damaging to his reputation and to the reputation of westminster .
he must deliver on that .
that promise to scotland was made in something as close to blood as you get in politics .
miliband has promised to protect the nhs from a looming funding crisis without raising taxes for everyday working people '' .
miliband has said that gordon brown is not going to come back to frontline politics in britain . ''
business leaders have critcised miliband 's proposal to increase the minimum wage to £ 8 during the course of the next parliament .

katja hall , the cbi 's deputy director general , said : the low pay commission is one of the biggest success stories of the last labour government and makes its judgements based on considerable independent expertise .
the lpc is not for politicians to play politics with .
the national minimum wage has enjoyed broad business support and a move to a politicised us-style system is not in the interest of companies or workers .
and simon walker , director general of the institute of directors , said : the only sustainable drivers of wage growth are productivity gains and improvements in company performance .
allowing wage rates to be determined by anything other than these measures would be a risky move .
but dave prentis , general secretary of unison , welcomedd the proposal , saying hundreds of thousands of public sector workers are on the minimum wage and that is a disgrace in the 21st century . ''

and paul kenny , the gmb general secretary , said this was a welcome and necessary first step for workers to recover the nearly 15 % drop in the value of earnings they suffered over the last six years . ''

labour would replace theresa may 's fundamentally flawed '' elected police commissioners with a new system making police accountable to police boards of council leaders and neighbourhood policing panels , yvette cooper has announced .
as alan travis reports , cooper said the party wants to give local residents a legal guaranteed that they can help decide local policing priorities and the number of police on the beat .
she said : there should be a policing contract with the local community , involving councillors but also giving the public direct access in public meetings .
the council and the chief constable should be jointly appointing the local police commander .

angela eagle , shadow leader of the commons and chair of the national policy forum , has told the conference that labour has pioneered a new way of making policy in our party , ending suffocating top down control '' .
in a speech introducing the npf report , she said : we really have built this policy platform from the grassroots up .
and in the autumn we 'll be doing more of the same as we work together to finalise our manifesto .
iain mcnicol , labour 's general secretary , has told the party that getting back to power after just one term in opposition is achievable .
in his speech to the conference he said : we face a great test on may 7 next year .
to bounce back after just one term in opposition - there are some who say it ca n't be done .
but you know what ?
we 're labour .
we do n't play by the political rules .
we write them .
we 'd never seen socialists elected until 1900 , when labour rewrote the rules .
we 'd never seen a labour government until 1924 , when labour rewrote the rules .
we 'd never seen two consecutive labour majority governments until 2001 , when labour rewrote the rules .

documents.title: no 10 suggests more powers for scotland not linked to english question
text: downing street is now playing down the suggestion that david cameron is directly linking further powers for scotland with cutting the voting rights of scottish mps .
this morning a number 10 spokesman put out this statement .
the three pro-union parties have made commitments on further powers for the scottish parliament and we have set out a clear timetable to do this .

lord smith of kelvin has agreed to oversee the process to take forward the devolution commitments with powers over tax , spending and welfare all agreed by november and draft legislation published by january .
this government has delivered on devolution and we will do so again in the next parliament .

documents.title: alex salmond 's interviews - summary
text: we 've had two alex salmond interviews this morning : one on sky news , and another on the daily politics , which was recorded yesterday but only shown in full this morning .
scotland 's first minister may be resigning , but he has no intention of abandoning his habit of stirring things up .
there were some important lines in the interviews .
here are the key points .
salmond said that if the uk were to leave the eu , that would trigger a demand for a second referendum on scottish independence .
he reaffirmed his view that the referendum should settle the issue for a generation .
but he said that circumstances could change , and he even hinted that westminster going back on its promise to give scotland more powers could also trigger a demand for a second referendum .
there are always things that can change circumstances in politics .
if the uk moved out of the european union , for example , that would be a circumstance .

some people would argue if the westminster parties [ break their promise that would be a circumstance too , salmond implied , but he did not finish the sentence ] i 'm actually not surprised [ about them ] reneging on their commitments .
i 'm only surprised at the speed at which [ they 're doing it ] .
they seem to be totally shameless in these matters .
he suggested scotland would not necessarily need a referendum to become independent .
my view on a constitutional referendum - this is my personal view - is as something you have in that style once in a generation , but , of course , there are many routes to independence .

the referendum route was one of my choosing ; it was my policy , i thought that was the right way to proceed , but of course there are a whole range of ways where scotland can improve its position in pursuit of scottish independence .
i think that 's going to happen .
he said he thought independence was now inevitable .
i think that 's going to happen .
when you have a situation where the majority of a country up to the age of 55 is already voting for independence , then i think the writing 's on the wall for westminster .
the destination is pretty certain ; we 're only now debating the timescale and the method .
now i 'll contribute to that debate , but i think it 's time for new leadership .
he said he was not surprised that david cameron was going back on his promise to give scotland more powers by linking this to english votes for english laws '' .
but people who were persuaded to vote no in the referendum were misled '' and gulled '' , he said .
he implied that labour and the conservatives were both guilty of letting down scotland .
david cameron does n't think he can carry his own backbenchers , never mind the threat from ukip , unless he links scottish progress to changes in england .
ed miliband does n't want to do that because labour would lose their majority over english business in the house of commons .
that is the log jam the westminster leaders got themselves into .
there is a big issue there , but should n't they have thought of that before they made a solemn vow and pledge to the scottish people .
he said he thought he was going to win through most of the campaign .
he said he did not agonise '' about whether to resign .
he decided at lunchtime on friday , he said .
i 'm not really an agoniser .
i take a look at things .
when you get beaten at an election or referendum , then you have to consider standing down as a real possibility .
he said there were many able people '' who could lead the snp .
he said he was writing a book about the campaign , 100 days , which would be out before christmas .
in it he would discuss what he could have done differently , he said .
he said he was not giving up politics .
he said the rocks would melt ' in the sun before he took a seat in the house of lords .
he was opposed to the lords , he said .
i 've taken some of the quotes from politicshome .
alex salmond lawson/pa
labour spin doctors are angry are angry about the way the media , and particularly the bbc , are presenting david cameron 's english votes english laws '' proposal as a challenge for ed miliband .

if cameron really is trying to say that further devolution for scotland is conditional on the voting rights of scottish mps being curtailed , then he is imposing retrospective conditions on the pledge given during the scottish referendum campaign and he deserves to get crucified '' for breaking his word , a senior party source said .
that would be one of the greatest betrayals '' ever .
and if he is not making it a condition , then cameron is going to get crucified by his own backbenchers , the source said .
this was not an issue for miliband , the source said , because the party 's position is clear .
labour is committed to further devolution for scotland as a priority , and will look at the question of england as a separate matter .
the labour mp kate hoey told sky news that she was in favour of scottish mps being banned from voting on english-only legislation .

the reality is it is n't fair , and it 's never been fair for the last while since there 's been devolution , that english mps have no say in what 's happening in scotland 's health service and education , but scottish mps have a say on ours .
i 'm very clear that the right thing to do is that scottish mps should not be able to vote on those big issues that are affecting england only .
the challenge is how we do it .
i do n't think we can do it between now and the general election , but we have to have it as a commitment that that will happen .
she also said that ed miliband 's plans for a constitutional convention suggested he did not see that as a priority .

the danger of what ed is saying about this constitutional convention , even if it might be the right thing to do , it looks like it 's just putting it all into the long grass and we do n't really care about england .
we must not have this idea that labour does n't care about england .
there 's got to be some pretty major things done quickly .

documents.title: alistair darling 's interview on marr - summary
text: alistair darling , the labour former chancellor and leader of the better together campaign , was on the andrew marr show too .
i summarised his interview very briefly at 9.31am , but it 's worth writing up in more detail , so here goes .
darling said that cameron would pay a very heavy price for years '' if he went back on his promise to give more powers to scotland .
trying to link that to limiting the voting rights of scottish mps was unacceptable , he said .
the agreement reached by the three parties , as far as i 'm concerned , is non-negotiable .
it was promised , it 's got to be delivered , and anyone who welches on that will pay a very heavy price for years to come .
it is simply non-negotiable the debate in scotland is altogether more advanced and more developed than it is in other parts of the uk because we 've had a referendum campaign .

i quite accept there is , alongside that but separate from it , a bigger issue about what constitutional reform is needed , but what i 'm very clear about is the agreement , the binding commitments given in relation to scotland are non-negotiable .
or put it another way - if anyone attempts to get out of that , how will anyone be believed on anything they 've got to say ?
that is simply non-negotiable , i 'm very , very clear about that .
he said the scottish referendum should settle the independence issue for a generation .

we 've settled it - we 've had the referendum that people did n't think would ever take place ; a massive turnout , which speaks volumes , but it 's been decided now for a generation , and by a generation i mean many , many years to come .
he said he did not believe the yougov poll putting the yes camp ahead .

i 've been involved in election campaigns for over 30 years , and i know that when you go around the supermarket and people , when they move away from you and are rather embarrassed to have you in the same supermarket as they are , you 've got a problem , but this was n't happening .
people were coming up and - sometimes quietly - saying 'i 'm on your side ' .
it was a very odd thing .

what i 'll tell you that poll did do , though , is it galvanised our support , because when it appeared , far from heads going down , heads went up , and you got people who had said nothing , for whatever reason , they said 'i 'm not going to let this happen to my country ' .
so it 's one of these things - a well-disguised blessing .
he said he had not yet decided whether to stand for parliament again .

i 've got a bigger decision to make in the next couple of weeks or so as to whether or not i stand again as an mp and i 've got to make that decision fairly quickly , but whatever i do , inside or outside parliament , i 'm not a spectator by nature .
i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .
alistair darling perry/epa

documents.title: ed miliband 's marr interview - summary
text: here is a summary of the key points from ed miliband 's interview .
i 've taken the quotes from the press association and politicshome .
miliband insisted that he was opposed to any attempt to link giving further powers to scotland to boosting the power of english mps .
and he revealed that david cameron said nothing about his plans to make such a link when they spoke about the joint cross-party promise to scotland before thursday 's referendum .
what william hague said very , very clearly on the radio on friday morning was as that these two processes he said that they did not depend on each other .

and i think that people right across the united kingdom will say 'well , david cameron made a promise ; he did n't make a conditional promise , he made a clear promise and he 's going to be kept to that ' .
miliband said the three main uk parties had to keep their promise to give scotland more devolution .
we 're going to deliver .
no ifs , no buts , we 're going to deliver on that promise .

he hinted that he would back plans to strengthen the rights of english mps set out in the mckay commission report , but said that he was opposed to a full ban on scottish mps voting in english-only legislation .

the mckay report came out last year , and it 's recommendations , which involve excluding scottish mps from voting when bills are being discussed in detail in committee , were designed to stop the house of commons having two classes of mps .
miliband backed this general approach .
there is n't a simple answer to this question .
we have been wrestling with this issue for 120 years , ever since we were talking about irish home rule .
i 'm open to the idea of greater scrutiny of legislation by english mps .
but we ca n't do it in a back of the envelope , fag packet way .
we spent two years trying to keep our country together - let 's have a proper constitutional convention , let 's look at these issues .
i 'm not in favour of a new parliament , a new set of politicians - i do n't think that 's the answer .

i am in favour of one house of commons , with 650 mps , because goodness we fought tooth and nail over the past two years to avoid our parliament being split up and our united kingdom being split up .
he said labour would protect the nhs budget and that it would unveil plans to go further to help health spending .
but he did not give details .
there would be an announcement at some point later , he said .
he said increasing the national minimum wage to £ 8 an hour would save the state money , because of the money saved in benefits .
he said the 45 % vote for independence in scotland showed how angry people are with the way with the way the economy works .
there is a huge danger that the political class is learning the wrong lessons from this referendum and from what is happening in britain .
i think constitutional change is important , but i think there is a much bigger lesson - a much bigger lesson and , in the words of bill clinton , it 's the economy , stupid .
forty-five per cent of people tried to break up our country by voting yes .
they thought they had nothing to lose , many of them , by saying 'let 's leave the united kingdom ' this was about how scotland is governed and how the uk is governed .
but more than that , it 's about how this country works : does it work for an elite few or does it work for most working people ?

unless the establishment recognises this wake up call about how our country is run , how our economy is run , we are not going to address discontent in england , wales , scotland and the whole of the united kingdom .
he ruled out giving gordon brown a job , saying he did not expect to see him coming back to a frontbench role in uk politics .
the independent on sunday 's political editor says this could be a hint .
jane merrick ( @ janemerrick23 ) ed miliband says gordon brown will `` not return to frontline politics in britain '' .
because he knows that gb in line for big world role ?
but he did not rule out giving a role to alistair darling , describing him as a very , very strong member of labour 's team '' .
he said he would only support air strikes in iraq and syria if they had legal backing , and strong regional support .
but he did not explicitly say there would have to be a un resolution for labour to support them .
ed miliband arriving at the bbc studios at media city in salford for his interview with andrew marr kitwood/getty images
q : would labour policy be different on the middle east and islamic state ?
miliband says his thoughts are with the family of alan henning .
we must assemble an alliance to counter islamic state ( isis ) , he says .
q : would you oppose military intervention ?
miliband says he supported action in libya .
there a clear case , and it was clear what military action would achieve .
he did not support action in syria .
there were alternative ways of dealing with the chemical weapons problem .
q : would you support air strikes without a un resolution .
miliband says it would have to have a basis in international law .
and there would have to be regional support , he says .
miliband says he does not see the minimum wage as just a labour core vote issue .
he wants all hard-working people to be rewarded .
q : why are you 20 points behind on the economy ?
miliband says he relishes the prospect of debating the economy at the election .
he wants the economy to work for the many .
creating jobs is a priority , he says .
q : but we are an indebted country ?
there would have to be cuts .
there would be a huge difference between a labour government and a conservative government .
labour will get the deficit down .
but it will speak for the country .
q : why not give 16 and 17-year-olds the vote , after they voted in the scottish referendum ?
miliband says he is in favour of this .
he did not originally support it for the scottish referendum .
but it was a success .
q : before you made your pledge with david cameron , did he raise the point about english votes for english laws ?
no , says miliband .
q : do you want to see alistair darling back on the front bench ?
miliband says darling has to decide what to do next .
q : what about gordon brown ?
miliband says he is not going to come back to frontline politics in britain .
q : will you raise more money ?
miliband says labour has already set out some : the 50p tax , and the mansion tax .
q : what about other measures ?
miliband says he does not want to raise tax for ordinary people .
q : do you think the nhs does n't have enough money ?
miliband says he is concerned about this .
q : will you protect its budget ?
miliband says labour will say more about this before the election .
q : what happens to hospitals on day one of a labour government ?
miliband says he would repeal the health and social care act .
that would get competition lawyers out of hospitals .
and he would ensure people can see a gp within 48 hours .
q : how much will this cost the public sector ?
miliband says this will save money .
it will have no cost to the public sector .
do n't believe me ; this is what the government 's figures say .
the institute of fiscal studies has said this too , he says .
q : does n't your pledge on the minimum wage amount to over-ruling the low pay commission ?
miliband says to the government has to take a lead .
the low pay commission has done an important job tackling the worst aspects of low pay .
but now more needs to be done .
people are struggling on low pay .
q : what do you say to groups like the cbi that say this could cost jobs ?
they said this before the minimum wage was introduced , he says .
they were wrong .
and labour is proposing to increase it over five years .
q : do you support the barnett formula ?
miliband says all party leaders support it .
it ensures money is allocated to scotland on need .
but money needs to be distributed in england more fairly .
q : would you accept english votes for english laws ?
miliband says he would look at any proposal .
but this is n't a simple issue .
q : yes it is .
no it is n't .
english mps vote on transport in london , even though this is devolved to the london assembly .
he says we must have a proper constitutional convention .
let 's not look this in a back-of-an-envelope , fag-packet way , he says .
q : this is because you would lose a majority in england .
that 's not the history , says miliband .
when labour wins in the uk , it wins in england too .
the local government association has backed a constitutional convention .
he says he is not in favour of a new parliament .
he wants one parliament , with one type of mps .
q : is there a case against having a class of english-only legislation ?
miliband says he is favour of more scrutiny .
but it is hard to distinguish .
look at tuition fees .
they apply to england , but have knock-on effects elsewhere .
and he says he is against having two classes of mps .
q : you said you would deliver on further scottish devolution .
will you deliver .
yes , says miliband .
no ifs , no buts . ''
q : why should scottish mps vote on english matters ?
miliband says william hague said on friday morning that these two processes - scottish devolution and english reform - would run separately .
he says cameron will want to keep his promises .
q : what is wrong with english votes for english laws ?
miliband says there is a problem with the fact that power has not been devolved to england .
the first solution is to devolve power to england , he says .
miliband describes meeting a woman in scotland saying she was voting yes because she could not get a council house .
another person supported yes because she wanted a pay rise .

documents.title: ed miliband 's interview on the andrew marr show
text: ed miliband says the political class is learning the wrong lesson from the scottish referendum .
constitutional change is important .
but there is a bigger lesson , and , as bill clinton said , it 's about the economy , stupid .
some 45 % of people in scotland wants to break up the uk .
that 's because they were unhappy with the way the system was working .
alistair darling , the labour former chancellor and leader of the better together campaign , has just been interviewed on the andrew marr show .
there were two key lines .
darling insisted that the cross-party pledge to offer more powes to scotland in the event of a no vote was not linked to constitutional reform for england .
that promise was non-negotiable , he said .
he said that he has still not decided whether to stand for parliament again in 2015 .
but he was not a spectator by nature , he said .
i 'll post the full quotes later .
david cameron has posted his daily mail article , and its challenge to ed miliband , on facebook .

david cameron ( @ david cameron ) why the rest of the uk must have the same powers that we are rightfully devolving to the people of scotland : it 's worth quoting from the article again , just to illustrate cameron 's breathtaking chutzpah .

he says the conservatives have been leading the way on further devolution to scotland and that labour ( the party that created the scottish parliament ) and the liberals ( who have been committed to home rule for more than a century ) have just been catching up .

it 's now the conservatives who are the keenest of all the parties in scotland to make devolution work by giving the scottish parliament real additional powers so its members take responsibility for their decisions .
and - by leading from the front on this - ruth davidson of the scottish conservatives has emerged as the party leader with the most enhanced reputation .
so for the conservative party , these proposals were not the work of a week , but of many months .
as far as we were concerned , the motor was already running and we just needed all three pro-uk parties on board before we could get going .
what makes this particularly shameless is the fact that davidson won the leadership of the scottish conservatives on a platform of being opposed to further devolution .
the scottish independence referendum is over and this morning , in manchester , the party conference season is starting .
normally , while one party has its conference , the other parties generally take the week off .

but , as the labour conference opens in manchester , it feels as if the scottish independence referendum campaign is far from over , because david cameron has chosen not to ignore labour for the week , but to challenge it to match his plans for english voters for english laws '' .
here are the stories dominating the news agenda today .
labour and the conservatives are at loggerheads over how to honour the promise to give scotland further powers .
in an article for the daily mail , david cameron insists that there must be a new settlement for england too .
when we change our constitution - how we are governed - a new settlement has to be fair and lasting .
forcing english people to accept policies on schools , hospitals and taxes for which they have not voted is not fair and such a settlement could not last .
of course , devolution is not just a matter for nations .
power can and must be devolved more locally .
i am a localist .
and he challenges labour to accept this .

at the start of the party conference season , the challenge to labour and ed miliband is clear : either resolve this issue with us , or explain to the people of the rest of the uk why they should n't have the same powers as we are rightfully devolving to the people of scotland - why , for instance , scottish mps should be able to vote to vary income tax rates in england , when the scottish parliament is going to be setting scottish income tax rates in scotland .

in an article in the sunday telegraph , chris grayling , the conservative justice secretary , goes marginally further , implying the conservatives will block further scottish devolution unless they get their way on english votes for english law '' .

we can not have a situation where more and more decisions about scotland are being taken in scotland , and yet scottish mps come to westminster and vote on english-only issues , shaping the destiny of health , education , justice , environment and probably taxation , too , in england , potentially against the wishes of most english representatives .
that would be a travesty of democracy , and would be regarded with fury by the english .
ed miliband , the labour leader , responds in an interview in the observer .
he accuses cameron of being partisan , and says he is opposed to a settlement that would create two classes of mps .
i look at the guy [ cameron ] - i mean , he has learned nothing .
he is totally narrow , partisan .
he did n't even talk about the desire for economic and social change , which is totally front and centre of this referendum mood and , indeed , the mood across the country .
we have just spent two years trying to keep our country together .
we should be incredibly wary of back-of-the-fag-packet solutions that create two sets of mps , two classes of mps .
why ?
because you have one prime minister of the united kingdom .
and nick clegg uses an article in the sunday times ( paywall ) to criticise both the conservatives and labour for their stance on this issue .
the conservatives , in their rush to protect themselves from an attack from the right , are concerned only about english votes on english matters .

of course we need a solution to this dilemma but , by appearing to link it to the delivery of further devolution to scotland , they risk reneging on the commitment made to the scottish people that , in the event of a no '' vote , new powers would be granted , come what may .
worse still , if the conservatives enter into a dutch auction with ukip over the issue of english votes , they could jeopardise the union they purport to defend .
surely we have n't fought to save our union in a vote north of the border , only to see it balkanised in westminster ?
labour , by contrast , appear to have been taken by surprise by the unavoidable consequences of devolving sweeping new powers to holyrood .

they are choosing to ignore the dilemma of non-english mps taking decisions on purely english issues miliband has said labour would significantly boost the national minimum wage to more than £ 8 an hour during the next parliament , giving many of britain 's lowest paid workers an increase of about £ 60 a week .
alex salmond , scotland 's first minister , has said no voters in last week 's independence referendum were tricked '' by a late vow of more devolved powers .
he made the point in an interview with the sunday politics , which i will be covering in detail later .
here 's the agenda for the conference .
11am : conference opens .

speeches from angela eagle , shadow leader of the commons and chair of the national executive committee , and iain mcnicol , labour 's general secretary , and party business , including scottish report and awards .

2.15pm : afternoon session , with a speech from tristram hunt , the shadow education secretary , a session on better politics with a speech by gloria de piero , the shadow equalities minister , and a speech from hilary benn , the communities secretary .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
